choices.C: Ensure vCenter Dump Collector service is running.
choices.D: Manually create scratch partition on the SD card.
choices.B: By default the log files will be stored on the SD card.
choices.A: Configure the scratch partition to use an available datastore.

discussion.content: A. Configure the scratch partition to use an available datastore.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator is installing ESXi 6.7 on a diskless host booting from an onboard 8GB SD card.
What should be done to ensure log files are persisted through a host reboot?

discussion.content: I think the Answer would be 3 as the memory reservation is 3GB, so, its C

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator creates a VM with 2 vCPUs and 4GB memory. A 3GB memory reservation is applied to the VM.
What size is .vswp file when the VM is powered on?
What are two features of the CPU scheduler? (Choose two.)

choices.E: allocates CPU and memory resource usage
choices.C: determines which worlds are entitled to CPU time
choices.A: creates a world for each virtual machine to run in

discussion.content: Very confident of B and C

Must be: BC

CPU scheduler has multiple functions - Schedules virtual CPUs (vCPUs) on physical CPUs - Enforces the proportional-share algorithm for CPU Usage - which vCPUs will be scheduled over others - Supports symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) VMs - up to 128 vCPUs per VM - Uses relaxed co-scheduling for SMP VM - The CPU scheduler chooses which world to schedule on a processoR

choices.E: VM Power User role on X-Lence Datacenter

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

A user requires full privileges on all VMs and templates in the X-Lence Datacenter except AZ-1000. This user must not be able to view or change the AX-1000
VM.
Which two permissions for this user should the vSphere administrator define to achieve this? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Do theses guys place deliberate typos to make you think? It must be the case! This answer is correct, but AZ / AX1000?

questions.question_text: What could a vSphere administrator use to move a group of VMs to another port group?

discussion.content:
Correct answer: D

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vcenterhost.doc/GUID-7DAD15D4-7F41-4913-9F16-567289E22977.html

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1010612

Network I/O Control =distributed vswitch feature to do traffic shaping/throteling
IP hash =used by vswitch for multiple uplink load balancing Network
Port Binding =used for iSCSI target multipathing access
vSphere vMotion =correct (the only one relevant to scenario)
Question is, moving vms to another port group, that means to different network port group
